qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: Mostly for calling my children and relatives. I use WhatsApp to see the photos my daughter sends. Sometimes I listen to devotional songs on YouTube, but only when my granddaughter helps me open the app.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: Yes, my granddaughter uses it to play games and watch cartoons when she visits. My husband also sometimes takes it to call someone if his phone is charging.

qa.question: What are your favorite apps or features on your phone?
qa.answer: WhatsApp is my favorite because I get to see my family’s photos. I don’t really think about what the apps collect. My daughter once told me not to click on anything new.

qa.question: When an app asks for permission, like access to location or contacts, do you read and understand what it means?
qa.answer: No, I don’t understand all that. If it says ‘Allow,’ I just ask my granddaughter or wait for my daughter to visit.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app or website is safe to use?
qa.answer: I don’t install apps on my own. My daughter does it. If she says it’s okay, I trust it.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted a message, photo, or app because you didn’t want someone to see it?
qa.answer: No, I don’t know how to delete things. But sometimes if I think a message is not nice, I ask my granddaughter to remove it.

qa.question: If your phone stops working and you need to give it for repair, what do you do before handing it over?
qa.answer: I give it as it is. I don’t know how to remove anything. I just hope the person repairing it is honest.

qa.question: Have you ever asked someone to help you with a phone problem?
qa.answer: Yes, my granddaughter or daughter. I feel shy when they look at my photos or messages, but I trust them.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: I only talk in person. I don’t type anything personal on WhatsApp. My children taught me to be careful.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: No, I don’t do that. But I sometimes say things in Malayalam if I don’t want others to understand.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: No, I only get help. I don’t understand much, so I don’t help others with that.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera or location?
qa.answer: No. I’ve never done that. I don’t even know where to find that setting.

qa.question: When you get a warning message (‘this app may harm your phone’), what do you usually do?
qa.answer: I get scared and don’t touch it. I wait for my daughter to come and look.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I don’t know. Maybe it helps it work better? I haven’t thought about that.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Not really. I don’t think there’s anything secret in my phone. But I worry they might break something.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your gallery or apps without asking?
qa.answer: I don’t know. I don’t check after giving it. I just pray nothing bad happens.

qa.question: Do you use a password or lock screen on your phone? Why or why not?
qa.answer: No. I forget the password. My daughter kept one once and I couldn’t use the phone for two days!

qa.question: Do you think local apps are safer than international ones? Why?
qa.answer: I don’t know the difference. I just use what my daughter installs. If it’s in Malayalam or simple English, I like it more.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand a phone or app setting?
qa.answer: My granddaughter or daughter. They explain it slowly and help me.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes. My daughter told me not to click on unknown links or messages. So now I don’t open anything unless she says so.

scenarios.Broken Phone: I would just give it to the shop. I don’t know how to remove anything. I ask the person to fix it carefully.
scenarios.Sharing with Family: If my husband or granddaughter uses the phone, I don’t worry. But if someone else uses it, I get nervous.
scenarios.New App Requesting Permissions: I wouldn’t install it. I wait for someone from my family to do it and tell me if it’s okay.
scenarios.Helping Elderly Relative: I’ve never done that. I’m usually the one being helped. I don’t understand these permission things.
scenarios.Using Someone Else’s Phone: If I saw a message or photo, I would close it and give the phone back quickly.
scenarios.Giving Away Phone: I wouldn’t know what to do. I would give it to my daughter to check and clean before giving it to someone else.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: That would confuse me. I thought deleting something meant it’s gone.
scenarios.Free Public WiFi: I never connect to such things. I don’t know how to.
scenarios.Lottery Call: I have had such calls. I don’t believe them. I tell them ‘no’ and hang up.
scenarios.Friend Needs Help: I don’t know how to send money, so I would ask my daughter to do it. I won’t do it on my own.
